page.title: 19Hazelbury Bryan Church
page.content: The church which stands next to the school is isolated from the rest of the village because of the ravages of the Black Death in the fourteenth century. It is dedicated to St. Mary and St. James. Although the building is essentially of the fifteenth century, there is little doubt that an earlier Norman church was built on the site. Only the font remains. Alice de Bryan was responsible for its rebuilding, including the tower, the nave, and the chancel. The tithe barn is still standing, and is now a listed building. The walls are original, and remnants of the old timbers are visible. The Church House was used as almshouses but fell into disrepair. Miss Violet Cross, a generous benefactor, made funds available for its renovation.
